stream_context.summary: Kaze began by demonstrating a new performance profiling tool, then worked on level design for a slide in Course 13. The majority of the stream was spent importing and integrating a large batch of optimized character models and assets from Biobak for the 'Oily Boily Bay' level, debugging the resulting visual and animation issues live.

development_findings.summary: A new, highly effective profiler and trace tool created by Sauraen was integrated, revealing that the game is idle ~76% of the time and is currently RSP bottlenecked.
development_findings.quote: This is the new profiler. It is pretty good... You guys have no idea how useful this is.

development_findings.summary: A large slide in Course 13 caused a memory crash, forcing Kaze to implement a new memory allocation system that ultimately improved performance by 400 microseconds.
development_findings.quote: When I first made this slide I ran out of memory... And because of that I did the whole memory allocation thing... and we gained 400 microseconds of computing time.

development_findings.summary: The game's controls are eight times more precise than the original Mario 64, an unintended but beneficial side effect of an optimization for sine and cosine calculations.
development_findings.quote: In Mario 64 you have 4096 angles. In this game you have 65336 angles. The controls are about 8 times more precise.

development_findings.summary: To fix a difficulty issue on a slide where obstacles were hard to see, Kaze chose to narrow the slide's geometry to naturally raise the camera's horizon rather than force a camera tilt.
development_findings.quote: I'm thinking we can be really cheap here and just kind of scale the slide down to half so that the horizon of the camera is higher.

development_findings.summary: Kaze integrated a large batch of updated and optimized assets from Biobak for 'Oily Boily Bay', including models for Womps, Wigglers, and Koopas, significantly improving the level's visual cohesion.
development_findings.quote: Oh, that's so much better. They really fit in the world now.

development_findings.summary: Kaze debugged and fixed a complex bug with a Wiggler enemy's pathing, discovering a logical error that was causing it to skip waypoints.
The game is currently in development on at least Course 13, an ice/cave level.

context_findings.summary: Kaze explained that his popular catchphrase 'Rambus goes vroom vroom' originated from his boredom with repeating technical jargon while writing a video script.
context_findings.quote: I was writing the video and as I was writing the video, I noticed I kept saying this optimizes memory throughput and I just got sick of it. So I just wrote Rambus goes vroom vroom into my notes over and over because I just didn't care and then people loved it.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expressed strong negative feelings about living in Germany, citing its bureaucracy and technological backwardness as reasons for his move to Canada.
context_findings.quote: Living in Germany sucks, I'm so glad I moved out.

context_findings.summary: Kaze articulated a core design philosophy focused on ensuring every element in a level is cohesive and serves a functional purpose within its environment.
context_findings.quote: I always think a lot about well-being. Does it work as a part of the area? Does it serve its purpose?

context_findings.summary: Kaze shared that he and his wife, Zeina, are expecting their first child, whose birth is imminent.
context_findings.quote: The child is not born yet. It was supposed to be born two days ago. But it still takes a bit of it. I guess it's not fully cooked yet.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is about to begin a two-month paternity leave and plans to use some of the free time for personal N64-related programming projects.
context_findings.quote: I'm still on two months of paternity leave. I'm gonna spend that time trying to optimize the operating system on my N64.

biobak.summary: Biobak provided a large batch of optimized assets for 'Oily Boily Bay', with a clear focus on performance by reducing bone count and material usage.
biobak.quote: Made both legs use the same bone, saves one bone. Baked helmet strap into the texture saves one material. Slightly updated geo and collision to match.

biobak.summary: Biobak's asset delivery included updated models and textures for Tox Boxes, Womps, Wigglers, and Koopas, which Kaze praised for fitting the level's aesthetic much better.
Kaze noted that Biobak's optimizations are crucial for helping the 'Oily Boily Bay' level achieve its 30 FPS target.

zeina.summary: Zeina is actively contributing 3D models for the game's new overworld.
zeina.quote: Zeina is making a bunch of 3d models and stuff. Zeina wanted to give making the new overworld a try.

zeina.summary: Kaze jokingly described a playful dynamic with Zeina, referencing their upcoming child.
zeina.quote: I'm gonna have Reyna and Zeina fight to the death. Soap, very HD.

key_stories.title: The Slide That Broke Memory
key_stories.summary: Kaze's ambitious level design for a slide pushed the engine's limits, causing a memory crash. The process of fixing it led to a significant, unexpected performance optimization for the entire game.
key_stories.challenge: A large, complex slide Kaze designed for Course 13 used so many collision triangles that it exhausted the game's memory, causing it to crash.
key_stories.process: Kaze identified that the crash was due to the high number of surface nodes needed for the slide's collision. This prompted him to re-engineer the game's memory allocation for collision surfaces.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze implemented a new memory allocation system that not only fixed the crash but also significantly optimized the game, resulting in a 400-microsecond performance gain.
key_stories.key_quote: When I first made this slide I ran out of memory. And because of that I did the whole memory allocation thing that I talked about earlier... and because of that we gained 400 microseconds of computing time.

key_stories.title: Wiggler's Wrong Turn
key_stories.summary: While integrating Biobak's new Wiggler model, Kaze discovered its pathing was broken. Through live debugging, he found a single, unnecessary line of code was causing the error and fixed it, showcasing his problem-solving process.
key_stories.challenge: A Wiggler enemy in 'Oily Boily Bay' was not following its path correctly, turning erratically instead of completing its circuit.
key_stories.process: Kaze debugged the issue live on stream. By printing the pathing variables to the console, he deduced that a conditional check was incorrectly causing the Wiggler to skip waypoints, and identified the exact line of code responsible.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze removed the single flawed line of code, which immediately fixed the Wiggler's behavior, allowing it to follow the path and trigger its new facial animations correctly.
key_stories.key_quote: That's why the path was so buggy at first because I was skipping waypoints... there was no reason for this to exist so now it's just removed.

key_stories.title: Origin of 'Rambus Goes Vroom Vroom'
key_stories.summary: Kaze reveals the origin of his famous 'Rambus goes vroom vroom' catchphrase. It wasn't a planned branding effort but an impromptu, authentic moment of frustration with technical jargon that accidentally became a community inside joke.
key_stories.challenge: While writing a video script, Kaze became bored of repeatedly using the technical phrase 'optimizes memory throughput' to explain a concept.
key_stories.process: Out of sheer boredom and frustration with the repetitive technical explanation, Kaze replaced the formal phrase in his personal notes with the silly, onomatopoeic 'Rambus goes vroom vroom'.
key_stories.outcome: The phrase made it into the final video and became an iconic and beloved catchphrase within his community, demonstrating how his authentic personality resonates with his audience.
key_stories.key_quote: I was in a state of just being fucking I don't care. So I just wrote Rambus goes vroom vroom into my notes over and over because I just didn't care and then people loved it.

open_questions.context: Kaze showcased a new, powerful profiler tool made by a collaborator, Sauraen, which provides deep insight into the N64's performance.
questions: What specific development challenge led to the creation of this new profiler?
Can you describe the collaborative process with Sauraen for developing a tool like this?
Now that you can see the engine's performance in such detail, what is the single biggest optimization you're hoping to tackle next?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned that his wife, Zeina, is creating 3D models for the game's new overworld.
questions: What is the overall vision for the new overworld that Zeina is helping to create?
How do you two handle the dynamic of being both lead developer and husband, and artist and wife? Can you share an example of a creative disagreement and how you resolved it?
Zeina, what has been the most challenging or rewarding part of learning to create 3D assets for an N64 game?

open_questions.topic: Impact of High-Precision Controls on Design
open_questions.context: The game's controls are 8 times more precise than the original SM64, which was an accidental byproduct of an optimization.
questions: Now that this high precision is a feature, how has it intentionally changed your philosophy for level design?
Do you design challenges specifically to take advantage of this new level of control?
Does this change create any new challenges, such as making it harder for players accustomed to the original game's feel?

open_questions.context: Kaze is about to begin a two-month paternity leave and mentioned he plans to spend time working on N64 OS optimizations.
questions: How do you anticipate fatherhood will change your perspective on game development or the themes in your games?
What are the realistic development goals for RTYI during your paternity leave?
How has the team prepared to handle development and communication while you are less available?

open_questions.context: Kaze is integrating a large number of assets from Biobak, who focuses heavily on performance optimization in his models.
questions: Biobak, can you walk us through your process for redesigning a classic enemy like the Womp?
How do you balance artistic vision with the strict technical limitations of the N64?
What does the feedback loop between you and Kaze look like? How many iterations does an asset typically go through?
